bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, July 27, 1943

div1.p: Kean complains that Lawrence Reed is not answering his letters. He comments on Laura Wood's new book on Reed. He is delighted with Truby's book and offers a suggestion to remedy a printing error.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, July 27, 1943

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
July 27 /43

div1.p:
Love has been out of town &
I have just now got in touch with
him, He says he will be pleased to
review your book. I told him I
would lend him my copy (which
I value much on account of your
inscription in it) but he said he
would get a copy from Phalsu-
Mrs. Walter Reed's address is Blue
Ridge Summit- Penna- not Md. tho. it
is only about 100 yards from the Md
line- which by the way is the famous Mason
and Dixon live- I feel much as you
do about Lawrence Reed- How a man
who makes it a rule not to answer
2
letters got to be a Major Gen- & Insp.
Gen - is a mystery to me- I wrote
him an important letter once &
didnt get any answer and I
spoke to Mrs Reed, his mother,
about it. Ok you must'nt need that
in Lawrence she said “he does not answer
my letters either”-

My Cornelia is now half through it & says it is charming and
so clear that it does not demand great learning to under
stand it.

I am so pleased to get the picture
of the two Barbaras. What a lovely
face the mother has! The little girl
looks as if she had been interrupted
in some important and interesting
preoccupation and didn't want her
picture taken anyway-
I am glad that you feel better about
laura Wood and her book. She dug
up a lot that I didnt know about-
3
Reed's early life and was very con-
scientious to get things accurate-
One thing I remember was the point-
whether the confederate women had
the use of a sewing machine, which
I questioned. After a somewhat care-
ful investigation in which I helped
her we found that a few were in
use in the towns, but that the wife of
a methodist preacher in the country
would have one was very doubtful-
So she left it out- I hope you will
give her a good word when you
write. I sat down last week and
devoted a day to re-reading your book
and I am more delighted with it
than ever- Col. Hench in a long telegram
to me says that he and I might feel like
C2
B5
4
God-fathers to it- and I am sure
that I am proud to feel in that or
any other relation to it- Just what
the God-father of a book does for it,
beyond drinking to its success
and bragging about it, I dont know
but I have certainly done that-
I haven't had anything except the telegraphic
night-letter from Hench since he got
his copy but that was a mouthful-
It was a pity that they left out the
key to the frontispiece & the inscription
I think that the only thing they could do
would be to put these on a separate
sheet and paste it in on the copies not
yet sent out. They could be furnished
separately for the copies already mailed
in any quantity as 40 for the 40 copies
that you have ordered. I am sure that
I would like one for my copy. It is the
least they could do to make amends for their
negligence. With many thanks for my copy
